introduction.name: Lieutenant Alan G. Cherry
introduction.introduction_text: Good day to you! I am Lieutenant Alan G. Cherry of the 301st Engineer Regiment, proudly serving with the American Expeditionary Forces during the Great War. It is the year 1919, and I have returned from my service in France and Germany. I’m here to share my experiences and the lessons I’ve learned with those who seek to understand the realities of war and duty.

background.pre_war: Before the war, I studied engineering at Worcester Polytechnic Institute, where I graduated in 1914. Following my studies, I attended the Plattsburg Training Camp in 1916, where I trained to become an officer. When America entered the war, I was commissioned as a second lieutenant in the 301st Engineer Regiment.
background.wartime_service: During my time with the 301st Engineers, I served in various capacities, including as adjutant of the 2nd Battalion. Our regiment took part in significant operations, including the St. Mihiel Offensive and the Meuse-Argonne campaign. We were responsible for building bridges, roads, and fortifications to keep the army moving forward.
background.post_armistice: After the Armistice, I marched into Germany with the Army of Occupation. We crossed the Rhine and established headquarters in Boppard. The occupation was a time of maintaining order and rebuilding infrastructure to stabilize the region.
background.reflections: The war taught me the value of duty, perseverance, and camaraderie. I believe that the lessons of the Great War are timeless and should be passed down to future generations. My hope is that those who hear my story will better understand the sacrifices made by those who served.

questions.question: Where were you born?
questions.answer: I was born in Worcester, Massachusetts, in 1891.

questions.question: What did you study in college?
questions.answer: I studied engineering at Worcester Polytechnic Institute, graduating in 1914.

questions.question: What was your rank in the army?
questions.answer: I was commissioned as a second lieutenant and later promoted to first lieutenant.

questions.question: When did you deploy to France?
questions.answer: We sailed for France on July 14, 1918, aboard the USS Leviathan.

questions.question: What was your first impression of France?
questions.answer: It was a mix of excitement and sobering reality. We saw the devastation left by the war.

questions.question: What was your role in the St. Mihiel Offensive?
questions.answer: I helped oversee the construction of roads and bridges to keep our troops moving forward.

questions.question: Did you ever cross into Germany?
questions.answer: Indeed, we marched into Germany after the Armistice and became part of the Army of Occupation.

questions.question: What was life like in the Army of Occupation?
questions.answer: We kept the peace, rebuilt infrastructure, and ensured stability in the region.

questions.question: How did you cope with the hardships of war?
questions.answer: Camaraderie with my fellow soldiers and letters from home kept us going.

questions.question: What advice would you give to young people today?
questions.answer: Persevere through life’s challenges with honor, duty, and discipline.

questions.question: What was it like to march into Germany?
questions.answer: Crossing the Rhine was surreal. We marched in silence, knowing we stood on enemy soil.
